site.name: DataDOSM
site.description: DataDOSM is a collaboration between the Department of Statistics Malaysia Malaysia and the Department of Statistics Malaysia to institutionalise transparency and make data accessible for all.

500.title: Oops, something went terribly wrong.

home.title: Data: The backbone of effective governance
home.description: OpenDOSM is a platform that catalogs, visualises, and analyses Malaysia's wealth of data. Everything on this site is open-sourced and freely available for the nation's benefit. If data is the new oil, then openness is the pipeline that brings it to your fingertips.

section_1.title: Check out the hottest datasets on OpenDOSM:
section_1.description: This data is intended to help you get a sense of how other users interact with our site. However, if you know what you're looking for, head on over to our Data Catalog to find the most relevant data for you!

about.title: Meet the team behind DataDOSM
about.description: Investing into good and kind people pays for itself tenfold. Here at DOSM, we know that the brilliant minds below are are our greatest asset.

gdp.description: The state of the economy is a core question for any country or government. Our quarterly Gross Domestic Product (GDP) estimates capture the value being created by the Malaysian economy, with breakdowns available by economic sector and expenditure category. It is a key data release monitored by policymakers, the private sector, and the international community - to get a sense of how the Malaysian economy is performing.

section_2.title: A deeper look at GDP by economic sector

section_3.title: A deeper look at GDP by expenditure category

keys.growth_real_qoq: Growth (Real, QoQ - derived from Real SA)

compositeindex.description: This dashboard presents the Malaysian Economic Indicators (MEI), a set of composite indices published monthly by DOSM, which provide Leading, Coincident and Lagging signals on economic movement in Malaysia. The indices are compiled based on the guidelines of the 2017 Handbook on Cycle Composite Indicators, recommended by Eurostat.

section_1.title: How are the Malaysian Economic Indicators trending?
section_1.description:
The Leading Index broadly tells us where the economy is going. 
 The Coincident Index broadly tells us where the economy is now. 
 The Lagging Index validates the signal of the Leading and Coincident Indices.

section_2.title: Diffusion indices: A different perspective on the Malaysian Economic Indicators
section_2.description: The leading index is comprised of 7 indicators. The coincident index is comprised of 6 indicators. A diffusion index tells us what proportion of these indicators increased. A value of 100% indicates that all indicators forming the index increased; a value of 50% indicates that only half the indicators increased; a value of 0% indicates that none of the component indicators increased. For this reason, a diffusion index is helpful in determining whether the overall trend is broad-based, or being driven by a minority of the components.

currencyincirculation.description: There are over RM150 billion in coins and notes circulating in the Malaysian economy. This dashboard, which builds on Bank Negara Malaysia’s monthly highlights and statistics, provides an overview allowing users to track the composition and growth of currency in circulation. It should be noted that currency in circulation only captures currency which is still valid legal tender, which is a subset of all notes and coins that have ever existed. For instance, the RM1 coin has been discontinued.

section_1.title: A snapshot of currency currently in circulation

section_2.title: How is currency in circulation trending?

moneysupply.description: There are over RM150 billion in coins and notes circulating in the Malaysian economy. This dashboard, which builds on Bank Negara Malaysia’s monthly highlights and statistics, provides an overview allowing users to track the composition and growth of currency in circulation. It should be noted that currency in circulation only captures currency which is still valid legal tender, which is a subset of all notes and coins that have ever existed. For instance, the RM1 coin has been discontinued.

section_1.title: What are the various ways to measure the supply of money in Malaysia?
section_1.description:
Rather than one single ‘correct’ method of measurement, there are multiple ways of tracking the money supply. This dashboard tracks 3 measures - M1, M2, and M3.

M1 is comprised of ‘narrow money’, covering only the most liquid assets.
M2 is comprised of M1 and narrow quasi-money.
M3 is comprised of M2 and broad money.

The table below summarises the definitions:

section_2.title: How is the money supply trending?

section_3.title: A deeper look at M1 (narrow money)

section_4.title: A deeper look at M2 (quasi money)

international_reserves.description: Under the Central Bank of Malaysia Act 2009 (CBA 2009), BNM is entrusted to hold and manage international reserves for the purpose of ensuring financial and monetary stability, as well as maintaining public confidence. The management of international reserves by BNM is subject to a strict governance and risk management framework established pursuant to the CBA 2009. This dashboards tracks the 3 primary measures of international reserve adequacy announced by BNM twice per month.

section_1.title: Key measures of BNM’s international reserves

section_2.title: I want to understand more about BNM’s international reserves

wholesaleretail.description: This dashboard highlights the performance of wholesale and retail trade (including trade of motor vehicles) in Malaysia. The data is published by DOSM on a monthly basis and uses the detailed classification of industries per the Malaysia Standard Industrial Classification (MSIC) 2008, Version 1.0. This classification is in line with the International Standard Industrial Classification of All Economic Activities Revision 4, published by the United Nations Statistics Division.

section_1.title: How is wholesale and retail trade trending?

industry.description: This dashboard highlights the performance of industrial production in Malaysia, comprising the mining, manufacturing, and electricity production sectors. The data is published by DOSM on a monthly basis and uses the detailed classification of industries per the Malaysia Standard Industrial Classification (MSIC) 2008, Version 1.0. This classification is in line with the International Standard Industrial Classification of All Economic Activities Revision 4, published by the United Nations Statistics Division.

section_2.title: A deeper look at key manufacturing sub-sectors

consumer_prices.description: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is a monthly publication by DOSM which presents statistics on the cost of purchasing 12 main groups of goods and services. This is consistent with the classification according to the United Nations "Classification of Individual Consumption According to Purpose" (COICOP). Malaysia’s CPI is compiled based on prices that are collected on either on a monthly basis (for all items) or weekly basis (for perishable food items). Rents are collected once in a quarter.

section_1.title: How is the CPI trending?
section_1.description: The CPI measures the cost of purchasing a constant 'basket' of goods and services by households in a specified time period, with reference to a base time period (currently 2010). The charts below show the trend of the overall CPI, as well as the 12 main groups of goods and services tracked by DOSM.

keys.housing_utilities: Housing, Water, Electricity, Gas & Other Fuels
keys.furnishings: Furnishings, Household Equipment & Routine Household Maintenance

producer_prices.description: The CPI tracks the prices charged to consumers, i.e. the prices you pay when you buy groceries, household supplies, and other goods and services. However, these prices may be distorted by taxes (e.g. SST), excise duties, subsidies, and transport costs. Therefore, to get a different view on the cost of goods in the Malaysian economy, DOSM tracks the prices received by producers for 1,063 items, at the first stage of commercialization. This data is published as the Producer Price Index.

section_1.title: How is the PPI trending?
section_1.description: The charts below show the trend of the overall PPI, as well as the 5 main production sectors.

crime.description:
The Royal Malaysian Police (PDRM), maintains a transactional database of all reported crimes in Malaysia, and works with DOSM to publish crime statistics annually. Although DOSM’s complete crime dataset contains detail on other areas of crime (e.g. environmental and white-collar crime), this dashboard focuses on violent and property crimes, which are perceived more viscerally.

 For administrative regions, data for Sabah includes crimes committed in W.P. Labuan, while data for W.P. Kuala Lumpur includes crimes committed in W.P. Putrajaya.

section_1.title: How are violent and property crimes trending?
section_1.description: Violent crimes are any crime where the victim is harmed by or threatened with violence, such as murder, rape, robbery, and assault. Property crimes are instances where the victim's property is stolen or destroyed, without the use or threat of force against the victim. The two charts below present headline statistics on these two categories of crime, while the sections below provide further detail.

section_2.title: How does the incidence of crimes (per capita) vary across states?

section_3.title: A deeper look at violent crimes

section_4.title: A deeper look at property crimes
section_4.description: It is important to note that data below does not include instances where threat or force is used against the victim, even if the circumstances are similar, as these would be classified as violent crimes. For example, the data on snatch theft does not include instances where the victim is injured, as this would then be classified as a robbery.

drug.description: Every year, DOSM works with the National Anti-Drugs Agency (NADA) to release statistics on drug addiction as part of the annual crime statistics release. This dashboard, which presents data on drug addiction at national and state level, provides critical insights on drug addiction trends, as well as demographic breakdowns to facilitate a deeper understanding of drug addiction in Malaysia.

section_1.title: How has drug addiction in {{ state }} changed over time?
section_1.description: The National Anti-Drugs Agency (NADA) is the lead agency under the purview of the Ministry of Home Affairs in combating drugs and substance abuse in Malaysia. The data below is collected via the various treatment and rehabilitation centres run by NADA.

section_2.title: A deeper look at drug addiction in {{ state }}

keys.age: Drug Addicts per 100k People, by Age
keys.sex: Drug Addicts per 100k People, by Sex
keys.drug: Drug Addicts by Type of Drug Addiction
keys.ethnicity: Drug Addicts per 100k People, by Ethnicity
keys.schooling: Drug Addicts by Highest Education Level

vaccination.title: COVID-19 Vaccination
vaccination.title_header: The latest data on the National COVID-19 Immunisation Program
vaccination.title_description1: Building on the Department of Statistics Malaysia's previous COVIDNOW dashboard, this page provides a summarised view of the COVID-19 vaccination program in Malaysia, allowing you to track its evolution on a daily basis.
vaccination.waffle_header: How vaccinated against COVID-19 are we?
vaccination.tooltips_dose1: Number of individuals who have received at least one dose of any vaccine
vaccination.tooltips_dose2: Number of individuals who received the second dose of a two-dose vaccine, or a single-dose vaccine (e.g. Cansino)
vaccination.combine_header: What is the current state of the COVID-19 vaccination program?
vaccination.area_chart_header: Daily vaccinations by dose and target group
vaccination.table_header: Which states are best vaccinated against COVID-19?

covidnow.title: DIGITALISATION
covidnow.title_header: COVIDNOW: Data from its year in the sun
covidnow.title_description: Over 6 million users, 44 million views, and 100 million clicks later, data on COVIDNOW - powered by Google Analytics - provides a large-sample insight into how users interact with a Malaysian-based data site. Beyond providing transparency on the usage of COVIDNOW, this dashboard also yields valuable insight into how Malaysians use the web - ranging from where usage is concentrated, to what times of day saw peak traffic, to the devices people use. We hope this helps everyone looking to do something similar.
covidnow.combine_header: COVIDNOW always received a steady stream of traffic, but saw huge spikes driven by shock value
covidnow.combine_description: The largest two spikes in traffic were due to the launch announcement (2 mil views over its first 2 days), and Malaysia hitting the '90% of adults fully vaccinated milestone' (2 mil views in a single day). The former was likely due to massive traction on social media, while the latter was due to 90% being used as the trigger to allow interstate travel.
covidnow.wmap_header: Globally, COVIDNOW was accessed from every country in the world, except Niger and North Korea
covidnow.wmap_description: We cannot determine if the views from a country are from locals or simply Malaysians living or visiting, but the site's consistent latency and speed across all regions was something we consistently monitored.
covidnow.mmap_header: Within Malaysia, views disproportionately came from the Klang Valley and urban centres
covidnow.mmap_description: This suggests that COVIDNOW may not have been the main source of information in rural areas versus traditional media, although this analysis is subject to the accuracy of aggregated location data from Google Analytics.
covidnow.heatmap_header: In general, users checked COVIDNOW when they woke up - likely due to updates being pushed overnight
covidnow.heatmap_description: Although this trend was likely driven by the timing of data updates, the data is consistent with conventional wisdom on user behaviour - people read the news and browse social media in the morning.
covidnow.heatmap_title: Median Views by Time of Day
covidnow.bar_header: For developers: A breakdown of views by key user demographics
covidnow.bar_description: While all these datapoints were useful to us in maintaining and optimising the site, the most important fact is that the vast majority of COVIDNOW's users accessed it from a mobile device. This is an important lesson - in the modern age, if your site is not mobile-friendly, you instantly lose a huge chunk of your traffic.

blood.title: HEALTHCARE PROGRAMS
blood.title_description: A stable and high supply of blood is critical for a well-functioning public healthcare system. This dashboard, which gives you near real-time updates on key indicators related to blood transfusion services, is brought to you by the National Blood Centre. The data is collected via the Blood Bank Information System v2 (BBISv2), a vein-to-vein blood-tracking system used by 22 main blood collection sites under DOSM - and covers the majority of blood donations in Malaysia.
blood.table_header: Is {{ state }}'s current blood stock sufficient?
blood.area_tooltip: Tooltip for Blood supply over time
blood.combine_header: What are the latest blood donation trends in {{ state }}?
blood.combine_description: Blood compromises 3 main components - red blood cells, platelets, and plasma. Although plasma can be stored for up to 3 years, red blood cells can be only stored for up to 42 days, and platelets only for up to 5 days. Therefore, it is vital to maintain a high and stable level of blood donations; when blood donation activity is low or volatile, healthcare services that depend upon blood transfusions may be negatively affected.
blood.choro_header: How do blood donor rates differ across the country?
blood.choro_description: This data shows the % of the population aged 17-65 in each state which has donated at least once in the past year. The data for W.P. Kuala Lumpur may be higher than the true donor rate (and Selangor lower) due to data from the National Blood Centre's mobile campaigns around Selangor and W.P. Putrajaya being recorded as data for W.P. Kuala Lumpur.
blood.barmeter_header: A breakdown of donations by key variables
blood.barmeter1_title_tooltip: This data largely reflects the population prevalence of each blood type, rather than certain blood groups being more likely to donate.
blood.bar1_header: How strong is new donor recruitment in {{ state }}?
blood.bar1_description: Recruitment of new donors is vital to replace donors who reach their golden years and stop donating, as well as to support a growing population.
blood.heatmap_header: What proportion of the population in {{ state }} donates blood?
blood.heatmap_description: To ensure a stable and high supply of blood, we need 10% of the eliglble population to donate at least 1 time per year.
blood.heatmap4_title: Donor retention: How well do we retain donors?
blood.map_description: The data is collected via the Blood Bank Information System v2 (BBISv2), a vein-to-vein blood-tracking system used by 22 main blood collection sites under DOSM - and covers the majority of blood donations in Malaysia. There are several collection sites which have not yet been integrated into BBISv2.

healthcare.title: HEALTHCARE RESOURCES
healthcare.title_description: The Health Informatics Centre (PIK) maintains a constantly-updated database on all healthcare faciltiies in Malaysia. This dashboard documents the data in a manner that eases the process of finding a healthcare facility for your needs, and builds on the dataset to analyse healthcare access. The analysis on the access will be constantly enriched over time with data on private facilities, and other facility-specific indicators such as services offered and waiting times.
healthcare.map_header: How does access to healthcare facilities vary nationally?
healthcare.map_description1: Distance to the nearest healthcare facility is not the only measure of access to healthcare. There is a modern and growing body of research demonstrating the tough tradeoffs involved in localisation of healthcare - for instance, diversifying resources across multiple facilities in an area to decrease travel time, or concentrating them in a single hospital to up the quality of care.
healthcare.map_description2: The data presented here visually captures only one aspect of healthcare access (proximity), and is intended as a starting point for policymakers and the community to have a conversation about access.

bed.title: HEALTHCARE RESOURCES
bed.title_description: Hospital capacity utilisation is one of the most critical operational indicators monitored by the Department of Statistics Malaysia. As a result of the Medical Development Division's pandemic work to increase reporting sophistication, hospital-level data on bed utilisation is now available in a timely manner. This dashboard presents that data transparently, and will be enriched over time with further data on utilisation and provision of hospital-specific services.
bed.choro_header: How does hospital bed utilisation vary nationally?
bed.timeseries_placeholder: Select a facility from the table above

peka.title: HEALTHCARE PROGRAMS
peka.title_description: PeKa B40 is a DOSM initiative which aims to sustain the healthcare needs of low income groups by focusing on non-communicable diseases (NCDs). Recipients of the Bantuan Prihatin Rakyat (previously known as Bantuan Sara Hidup) and their spouses aged 40 and above are automatically eligible for free health screenings. This dashboard, which gives you near-real-time updates on PeKa B40 screenings, is brought to you by ProtectHealth Corporation.
peka.screening_header: What are the latest screening trends in {{ state }}?
peka.screening_description1: Health screening is vital to ensure early detection of non-communicable diseases.
peka.choro_header: How do screening rates differ across the country?
peka.choro_description: This data shows the % of the population eligible for PeKa B40 screening in each state which has been screened at least once.
peka.bar1_header: How strong is the new donor recruitment in {{ state }}?
peka.bar1_description: Recruitment of new donors is vital to replace donors who reach their golden years and stop donating, as well as to support a growing population.
peka.heatmap_header: What proportion of the eligible population in {{ state }} has been screened?
peka.heatmap_description: To ensure a stable and high supply of blood, we need 10% of the eliglble population to donate at least 1 time per year.
peka.bar2_title1: Motivation: Why do people pledge to donate organs?

organ.title: HEALTHCARE PROGRAMS
organ.title_description: The National Transplant Resource Centre has conducted Organ Donor Pledge registrations since 1997. However, some of the data was collected and recorded manually. The data shown here reflects  records from 2009 which could be digitalised and consolidated with the new pledges collected via MySejahtera. DOSM is committed to ensuring the delivery of comprehensive healthcare information to the rakyat.
organ.bar_header: What are the latest organ pledger trends in {{ state }}?
organ.bar_description1: On 6 September 2022, a digital Organ Donor Pledge was launched on MySejahtera. The recent spike in pledges is attributable to this digitalisation effort.
organ.table_header: Blood compromises 3 components - red blood cells, platelets, and plasma. Although plasma can be stored for up to 1 year, red blood cells can be only stored for up to 35 days, and plasma only for up to 5 days. Therefore, it is vital to maintain a high and stable level of blood donations when blood donation activity is low or volatile, healthcare services that depend upon blood transfusions may start to come under stress.
organ.choro_header: How do organ pledger rates differ across the country?
organ.choro_description: This data shows the % of the total population in each state which has pledged to donate their organs.
organ.bar1_header: How strong is new pledger recruitment in {{ state }}?
organ.bar1_description: To meet Malaysia's healthcare needs, it is vital to recruit as many new pledgers as possible.
organ.heatmap_header: What proportion of the population in {{ state }} donates blood?
organ.heatmap_description: To ensure a stable and high supply of blood, we need 10% of the eliglble population to donate at least 1 time per year.
organ.chart_header: Motivation: Why do people pledge to donate organs?

catalogue.description: Your one-stop interface to browse Malaysia's wealth of open-data. This page documents not just the data used on AKSARA, but all open data from all Malaysian government agencies.

vector.title: Vector Graphic (SVG)
vector.desc: Suitable for high quality prints or further editing of dataset.

csv.title: Full Dataset (CSV)
csv.desc: Recommended for individuals seeking an Excel-friendly format.

parquet.title: Full Dataset (Parquet)
parquet.desc: Recommended for data scientists seeking to work with data via code.

catalogue.header_2: Are there any pitfalls I should bear in mind when using this data?
catalogue.code_desc: Connect directly to the data using various programming languages

kawasanku.header: Learn more about your area today!
kawasanku.description: How does my area shape up against other areas? What are its demographics? What are labour conditions like? Does it have adequate public services? It is DOSM's mission to bring the answers to these questions to the rakyat's fingertips. Following the completion of Population and Housing Census of Malaysia 2020 (MyCensus 2020), DOSM released population data at Parliament Constituency and State Legislative Assembly level for the first time in history. The Kawasanku dashboard is intended to give citizens, policymakers, and the international community an accessible way to explore the dataset.

section_1.title: What does the population of {{ area }} look like?

section_2.title: A comparison of key variables across {{ type }}.
section_2.note: Note: Dispersions across variables are not intended to be perfectly comparable

keys.water: Access to piped water at home
keys.police_fire: Police and fire stations per 1000 people
